When AmaButho goes out for whatever reason, we use this.  We still use this Ntelezi even now.
Is it not correct that the Ntelezi is used to make the AmaButho brave so that they will be protected and do well in war, isn't that what it is for?
That is our belief as Zulu's.
And in fact, that was your belief on the night and the Ntelezi was used, it was drank and it was also poured or sprinkled over the weapons, is that right?
I am saying that any instance where AmaButho would have to go out, we use this Ntelezi.
I am asking you about the night of the attack, on that night, did the residents drink Ntelezi?
Yes, that is what I am saying.
And did they sprinkle the Ntelezi or pour the Ntelezi over their weapons?
There were a number of people who were given AK47's, is that correct?
There were also people with revolvers and shotguns?
Yes, I think so, even though it was night, I am not in the position to specifically indicate who was carrying what kind of a weapon.  I think yes, that was the case.
And we know that there were also spears and axes?
Then he says we all left by feet in the direction of the township, that is also correct, is it not?
And he says we were about 100 people.  Most of us were from the hostel, but I believe that there were some people from Natal amongst the attackers.  Correct or not?
Yes, the majority of us came from Natal, that is why we resided at the hostel.
Some of the attackers were wearing red head bands, is that correct?
Not some of them, all of them.
Isn't it that some were wearing red and some were wearing white or am I wrong?

I do not remember quite well, but I remember using red head bands, but yes, all of us were wearing head bands, I cannot remember whether there were some white head bands.  I don't want to agree with you when you say there were white head bands used as well, no.

It is not me who says that, it is Victor Mthembu who says that.  I will move on.  He says we walked on the road and passed under the bridge, which is located a few minutes' walk from the hostel, that is correct, is it not?
When we came out on the big open field before the township, I saw four to six caspirs parked on the field.  Your comment?

I did say earlier on that I saw only one caspir, it was just driving passed.
	I don't know anything about two or three or four caspirs.

It is correct that you came out into a big open field before you entered Boipatong, am I right?  After you passed under the bridge, you came out into an open field?  Just before?  Isn't it that you went behind the nursery and then you moved towards the lower side of Boipatong, or is that not the way it happened?
No, I do not recall that.

Where do you say you entered Boipatong, do you say it was at the top of Boipatong not at the bottom?
	When I talk about the top, I mean along that road where the factories are, Cape Gate and all of those factories, you entered Boipatong from that side?
If you are  following the route from Vanderbijl, I would say yes, that is the route that we took to gain our entry.
You have told the Court that you know where Umzimvubu Street is, right, the Committee?
Did you enter Boipatong along Umzimvubu Street?
No, further down.  It was further down Umzimvubu Street.
You spoke about a caspir that you saw whilst you were moving towards Boipatong, am I right?
Do you remember what colour caspir it was, or what type of caspir?
I do not remember.  I cannot remember whether it was a military caspir or a police caspir, I cannot recall really, it was at night.
And this caspir was moving alone, would it be Frikkie Meyer Boulevard, the main road that separates kwaMadala hostel from Boipatong, is that the road that the caspir was moving along?
And moving in which direction, moving towards...
In other words up towards the top of Boipatong?
And weren't you afraid that you might get caught?
I did indicate earlier on that this did not occur to me.  I think you are asking me this question for the second time now.
Yes, I am asking you now, when you saw this caspir, you were still not afraid that you might get caught, am I right?

We did think that it might be possible for us to be arrested, but the caspir proceeded on.  Had it stopped, yes, we could have concluded that now we were going to get arrested, but the caspir did not stop at all.

I put it to you that the caspirs were there, that in fact, there was more than one caspir, and that in fact, members of the AmaButho, some of them, actually got into the caspir and were transported into Boipatong.  Isn't that what happened?
Do you know a policeman by the name of Rooikop?
I only know him to be Rooikop.
Is this a black or a white policeman?
He is a white one.   I know a white one.
Is he thin or is he fat?
He is stout, not very big.
Now, Rubin, do you know someone by the name of Rubin?
That is Rubin Tebogo Magubane, correct, applicant 3?
He was present during the attack, am I right?
I did say earlier on that I do not remember Kachene.
You don't know who that person is, or you don't remember if he was there during the attack?
I did say that I know Kachene, My Lord, but all I am saying is that I cannot remember whether he was present on the day of the attack or not.
Was he present during the attack?
He is Sthembiso's brother.  He died.
Lucky, do you know who Lucky is?
He was there during the attack, am I right?
His real names are Sonny Michael Mkwanazi, applicant 7?
I do not know his real names really.
There are two Sipho's that I know.
The one is Sipho Buthelezi, right?
The other one is Sipho Lukhozi.
And that is Sipho Thomas Lukhozi?
And both of them were present during the massacre, am I right?
Makuka, do you know someone by that name?
I don't know his names, I just know him to be Makuka.
Do you know where he died?
No.  On coming back from home, I learnt that he had died.
And he was present during the massacre, correct?
No, I do not remember that one, I don't think I know him.
He was present during the massacre?
Yes, I think he was present.
That is Jack Mbele, applicant 6, correct?
And Makheze?  Do you know Makheze?
Chairperson, it is half past three.
We will rise now and come back at ten to four.

(continued)  Mr Mkhize, I take it that  you deny that there were any policemen involved in the attack on Boipatong?  You deny that there were any caspirs involved in the attack on Boipatong and you deny that there were any people wearing balaclavas who took part in the attack on Boipatong, would that be right?
If there had been caspirs involved in transporting some of the attackers to Boipatong, you would have seen that, am I right?
Yes, I would have seen them.
If there had been policemen involved, or whites involved, or people wearing balaclavas, you would have seen them, am I right?
And so the fact that you did not see any of this, means that they were not there, correct?

I want to put it to you that you are not telling the truth with the Committee and that there were in fact policemen involved, there were whites involved, there were people wearing balaclavas, whites wearing balaclavas and there were caspirs which transported attackers to the township.  You don't wish to comment?

My intention to come before this Committee is to seek amnesty and therefore would have no reason to hide any information if I had it.  I would have no reason to fear anybody including the policemen.  If there were policemen involved, I would say so.
	As I have already mentioned that I was present, I was armed with an AK47 and I do not know why I will be afraid to divulge information if I had it.    I am here to tell the Committee, to inform the Committee of what I saw and what I know.  Therefore I cannot say that the police were there if I did not see them.

You have every reason not to tell the truth Mr Mkhize, because if you do tell the truth, you fear that something will happen to you, something bad will happen to you.  We have seen with Mr Nosenga.  He has made an affidavit which sets out the truth, he is being threatened with his life.
	Isn't that what you fear?
No, it is not what I fear.  I don't even want to involve myself in Nosenga's issue, because I don't even know him.

Two of the policemen who gave evidence at the Goldstone Commission about police involvement in the attack, are dead today.  That is the reason that you are not telling the truth.  You are too scared to tell the truth and you are too scared to tell this Committee that that is the reason, isn't that right?
I am not afraid of anything.  I do not fear anything, I would say if there were policemen involved.  I don't really understand what I would be fearing.
You do know that you can be put into a witness protection programme if you tell the truth, if you fear for your life?  You know that?
You can be put into a witness protection programme if you are fearing for your life, you know that?
No, I do not know that.  With regards to what you are discussing here, there is nothing that I am afraid of.  I would not fear to divulge that the police were present if they were.
Are you not afraid of Prince Vanana Zulu?
No.  Would I be afraid that maybe he would assault me?
While we are on the subject of Prince Vanana Zulu, is it not correct that he was in fact part of the attack, that he was in Boipatong during the massacre?
I have already told you that he was absent.
What do you know about women who were raped during the massacre?
I do not know anything about that.

During the criminal trial, Lucky Stikenawu, Sonny Michael Mkwanazi, was asked the following question at page 3499 - he was asked, Gobi also said that on the 18th of June, that would have been the day after the massacre, you had a conversation with him and you told him that the previous night you had raped somebody in Boipatong.  Do you remember that evidence at the criminal trial?
That Lucky had said to someone who gave evidence for the State, that he had raped somebody in Boipatong, you don't remember that?
Did any of your men brag after the massacre that they had raped women in Boipatong?
No, I do not remember anyone doing that.  I did not get to hear of it.
Would it surprise you, does it surprise you that women were allegedly raped in Boipatong during the massacre?
Did you give instructions that women should not be raped?
No, I did not.  It was not something that would happen, if you go out to attack, you would also engage in raping women.
Did you give instructions that there should be no looting?
Normally when you are engaged in fighting, there is no time to be also engaged in looting.
So did it surprise you to learn that there was large scale looting during the massacre?
Yes, it did surprise me when I heard that some people's property had been looted.
Did you give any instructions that women and children and old people should not be harmed during the attack?
Even though there was no direct instruction to that effect, the people that we had actually targeted were SDU members, who I suppose were not children and were not elderly people.
Did you give any instructions that no property should be damaged during the attack?
We did not discuss property, we did not discuss people's property when we were actually discussing the attack.
You say it surprised you that people plundered and looted property during the attack, that surprised you, am I right?
Yes, that is what I said.
Why do you say in your statement, on page 77 at the bottom, that you gave the instruction to plunder?
This must have been a mistake.

Oh no, let me read to you what you said in your statement.  An instruction was given by me, to break the windows of the houses, and to loot and plunder.
	You confirmed this statement this morning.
I do not have knowledge thereof, I did not instruct anybody to break windows.
Just as you didn't instruct anybody to rape and just as you did not instruct anybody to kill women and children and old people, just the same?
Isn't it correct that anyone and anything, no matter how old, how young, anyone was a target in Boipatong?  Wasn't that the order when the attack began?

No, that was not the instruction.  The people that we targeted in Boipatong, were SDU's.  I do not dispute that other people were also injured, because as it happened, it was dark and we could not see clearly who was who.
You don't dispute that there were IFP members living in Boipatong, who were injured or killed during the attack?  You don't dispute that?

I do dispute that.  There was no IFP member residing in Boipatong at that time, because people had been killed and some of them had even fled the area, they had actually fled to kwaMadala hostel.
	I don't believe that there was any IFP member living in the area at the time.

Themba Khoza the leader of the IFP in the Transvaal said both during the criminal trial, and in press statements immediately after the attack, that there were IFP members and supporters living in Boipatong and it was ludicrous to think that the IFP could be responsible for an attack on their own people.
	Was Mr Khoza not telling the truth when he said that there were IFP members living in Boipatong and sympathizers?

I would not be able to dispute that, that must have been his knowledge, but as far as I know, there were no IFP people living in Boipatong at that time.
	He must have been referring to something that he knew.

Isn't it correct Mr Mkhize, that there was no way in which you and the other attackers could say as you rampaged through Boipatong and Slovo Park, could say whether that particular person was a member of the ANC, a sympathiser of the ANC, a member of the IFP, a member of the SDU, you just didn't know.  You went through the township, killing everyone and anyone who didn't have a red or white band around their forehead, isn't that in reality what happened?
What I am saying is that there was no IFP member living in Boipatong at that time.  What I did mention also, was that there was no control at that time, when the attack took place.
And that is because an order was given to kill everyone and anyone in Boipatong, in fact to destroy the entire township, isn't that what the order was?
I do not know how many times do I have to repeat myself.
Well, when you got into Boipatong, you fired you say in your statement, at a Self Defence Unit near the shops.  Am I right?
Did they fire back at you?
And then did you run after them as they ran away?
Yes, we did chase after them, but we could not catch up with them.
So then why did you and your men start destroying houses and going into houses in Boipatong?
I said I do not know about that, because that happened because people were out of control, you could no longer control them.
But you too, you also went through the township?  You were moving through the township and you were firing as you moved through the township, isn't that right?
You yourself, were moving through Boipatong and you were firing as you were going along.  Were you also out of control?

At page 78 you say, a third of the way down, you said it was dark and we were many.  We moved through the residential area and there was sporadic gunfire.   You yourself were going through, is that right, shooting as you went?
I said I actually fired when I saw people near the shop, but I did not shoot at random in the streets.
So you only fired at the shops, is that all?
Yes, that is right.  I would say yes, I did shoot near the shops and although I cannot remember if that was the only time, I cannot remember firing at any other point.
And you don't know if you killed anybody?
You never fired any shots in Slovo Park?
Yes, I did fire when we were at Slovo Park.
You never saw any dead people in Slovo Park?
You only learnt the following day that people had died during the attack, you did not know that night that people had been killed?

I want to read to you what you said in your statement to the police, Exhibit E.  You said we were a big group - let me start at page 4 - you are talking about being at the stadium and you talk about a person Situndwa Zulu.  Who is Situndwa Zulu?
I don't remember such a person.
You say in your statement page 5, that I had an AK47 with me with a magazine which was full of AK47 bullets, is that correct?
In other words, this is the truth what I have just read?
You also say page 5, that you left the stadium and you went across the road, you crossed the road which runs next to the hostel, to where the houses begin, which is correct, am I right?
Then you say when we came to the houses, those who had assegai's went into the houses, to stab the people.  Is that correct?
I think so, although a long time has elapsed since.

Then you say I and the others who waited outside, shot at those people from the houses, who ran outside and were trying to run away.
	So what you are saying is some AmaButho with spears, went into the houses to stab the people and as the people were coming out of the houses to run away, you and others stood there with your AK47's, and shot at them.  That is the truth, isn't that?
So it is not true that you only fired shots at the shops and in Slovo Park?
I did also say that I also fired with my firearm when we were going towards Slovo Park.
You say in the statement that you fired five shots with your AK47 at people who were running away?  Is that true?
I don't think it was five times.  It could have been more.
Did you empty your magazine in Boipatong and Slovo Park?
How did the attack come to an end, how did you know that the attack was ending?
When we assembled at Slovo Park, we just turned back and returned home.
Hundreds of you in Slovo Park?
All the AmaButho finally got to Slovo Park, is that what you are saying, and then you turned back?
Yes, we returned to the hostel thereafter.
But you hadn't attacked the whole of Boipatong, certain areas were left out, why?
We realised that if we were to continue, we would end up being arrested.
And when did you realise this?
When we assembled at Slovo Park, we decided that we should actually return to the hostel.
It suddenly dawned on you after an hour to an hour and a half, that the police might come and arrest you?
On your way back to kwaMadala, did you see any police or army vehicles?
The problem with you is that you ask me one and the same question.  I did say that I only saw one car.

The problem Mr Mkhize is that you don't listen to my question.  My question is as you were moving back to kwaMadala, did you see any police or army vehicles?  The vehicle that you spoke about was the vehicle that you saw when you were moving towards Boipatong.
I said I saw that vehicle on our way back.  It was proceeding towards Sebokeng.  I did not say I saw it on our way to Boipatong.

So if that vehicle had stopped, the one that you saw on your way back, if it had stopped, then you would have done what, because I remember your answer before was, if the vehicle had stopped, then we wouldn't have continued to go and attack?  Please explain what you would have done if it stopped?
He didn't, he didn't say that.  He said we would have run away.  We would have known that we would be arrested.

Chairperson, my recollection of the witness' evidence is that on their way to Boipatong, they saw this vehicle moving along Frikkie Meyer Boulevard.  If the vehicle had stopped, they would have known that they would have been arrested, they wouldn't have continued going towards Boipatong.  The vehicle continued driving.
He didn't add the part that you are adding.
The witness said that they were on their way to Boipatong.
His original evidence was that he saw this motor vehicle when they were on their way, that is what he said initially.
Not on their way to Boipatong?

That was his initial evidence.  Under cross-examination when there was a confusion, when he said this motor vehicle was proceeding towards Sebokeng I think it was, and it was put to him that they were on their way to Boipatong.

And he said yes?  Anyway, it is on record.  Mr Mkhize, then to clarify, is it your evidence that on your way from kwaMadala to Boipatong, you saw no vehicles, no army, no police vehicles as you were approaching Boipatong?
Yes, that is correct.  I did not see any vehicle.  I did not see any army vehicle, nor police vehicle.
And the caspir that you referred to, that you saw driving towards Sebokeng, that is the caspir that you saw on your way back to kwaMadala?

I put it to you that you are changing your evidence, but I will argue that.
	The caspir that you saw, or the only caspir that you saw, you say if it had stopped, then you might have been arrested, but it didn't stop, it continued going towards Sebokeng?
If it had stopped, what would you have done?
We would have run away.  There was no other option, except to flee.

We know that there was in fact a military vehicle stationed near the corner of Frikkie Meyer Boulevard and Nobel Boulevard, that is where that Trek garage was, we know that that - I believe it is either a caspir or a buffel, was stationed there as you were making your way back to kwaMadala.  Are you saying that you never saw that vehicle?
No, I did not see it.  The only vehicle that I saw, is the one that I mentioned before.
And that is the vehicle which did not stop, it continued driving towards Sebokeng?

In fact, we know that soldiers got out of that vehicle and stopped the traffic from proceeding, this is the vehicle traffic from proceeding along Frikkie Meyer Boulevard, in your direction.  You never saw that?
No, I did not see it.
So there was no reason for you to run, and I take it you did not run?
We did not run because the vehicle did not stop.

And hundreds of armed men, carrying looted property with blood dripping from spears and blankets, walked from Boipatong back to kwaMadala along the same route that they had taken to come out of kwaMadala, is that right?
Walked under the bridge again, along that road, and re-entered kwaMadala through the main gate?
Nobody went running and hiding in the marsh or the veld outside kwaMadala, you all entered through the main gate?
Yes, we all went through the main gate.

How is it that you only became aware that property was looted from Boipatong, the following morning?
	Remember you said you only became aware the following morning?
Yes.  I just heard rumours that some things had been looted from Boipatong.

But you were the Commander of these men, surely you remained behind until all your men had got into the hostel, so that you could be satisfied that they had safely returned to base, isn't that what you did as a Commander?
Yes, I should have, but it did not happen because we all went through the gate at the same time.
And you went from the gate, you went to the stadium, you went back to the stadium, didn't you?
No, that is not so.  We went to our rooms.

Let me read to you what you said to the police, page 5.  When we were finished with the attack, the whole group returned to the hostel.  We again went or assembled at the stadium, and Situndwa told us to hide our weapons away.
I do not know anything about this statement.

Well, it is your statement.  Is there any reason why you would have lied about re-assembling at the stadium if you didn't re-assemble at the stadium?  There would be no reason to tell such a lie, would there be?

I did mention before that a lot of what was said or a lot of statements that were made to the police, were under duress because we were being assaulted at the time.
	There was no person who could have given me an instruction because the only single person who was the Prince, was away.

We know that large items were looted from Boipatong.  We know that there was a grandfather clock, there were TV sets, there were quantities of meat stolen from freezers, there was a lot of heavy stuff looted from Boipatong, big stuff.
	Are you saying that you were unaware of anyone carrying such heavy stuff back to the hostel?
I said it a long while ago, that I was not aware of any property being looted when we returned to the hostel.

Mr Nosenga says that he himself, took a TV set and money, he put the TV into a caspir and he says that there were other TV's, hi-fi's, blankets in the caspir when he put his in.  He says that all of this looted property was transported back to the hostel in the caspirs.
I would like you to disregard what Nosenga is saying, because even the fact that there were police present there, is a mistake, that is not true.

By the way, whilst we are on the question of mistakes, in your statement on page 77, you talk about white bands, two thirds of the way down, white bands being handed out to wear as head bands before the attack.  Would that also be a mistake?
I did not say it was a mistake.  I said there were those head bands.
You specifically said there were no white head bands, didn't you or am I wrong?
I said I did not remember clearly whether it was red or white head bands that were used.
Mr Nosenga says that after you returned to the hostel, you all washed using a certain muti which was provided for by Chief Mtwana Zulu.  You were all happy and chanting and singing.
So when you got back to the hostel, there was no celebration that you had finally destroyed the enemy in Boipatong, you all just went back to your own rooms, there was no ...
We just went back to our rooms.
There was no discussion at all about the attack?
No.  There was no discussion because it was late at night.
What did you do with your weapons?
The next day, the 18th, is it correct that Themba Khoza came to the hostel?
I do not remember quite clearly, but I think he did arrive at the hostel, that was the day when he actually pleaded with us to cooperate with the police.

You were asked this question, question 22 on page 68, did Mr Themba Khoza and Mr Humphrey Ndlovu visit kwaMadala after the attack and your answer, page 74, paragraph 22, is yes.
	So you admit that Themba Khoza and Humphrey Ndlovu did come to the hostel?
That was the following day, that was when Themba Khoza said you must cooperate with the police?
Yes, I think it was on the following day.  If not that day, it could have been the 19th, but I think it was on the following day of the attack.

Then you were asked in paragraph 22.1, page 68, to give particulars of the nature of this visit and your answer was that they, that is Themba Khoza and Humphrey Ndlovu just wanted to find out what had happened.  We denied all allegations.
Do you say that that is correct?
You denied the allegations because you knew that the attack was not IFP policy, is that right?

Then you were asked did Mr Khoza warn hostel dwellers at a meeting that they should burn all the evidence that linked the attackers to the massacre, including goods stolen from the hostel, and clothes stained with blood, and that should read including goods stolen from Boipatong and clothes stained with blood, and your answer was no.
	Mr Themba Khoza did not instruct that the evidence should be burnt.  Is that still your answer?
You know that Mr Victor Mthembu contradicts you.  He says Themba Khoza did come, Themba Khoza did instruct that the evidence should be burnt.  Why should he say such a thing if it is not true?
I do not know.  I did not hear Mr Khoza saying that.

He is not alone on this, because - I am sorry, I am just trying to find out who it is - no, I am incorrect, what Mr Nosenga says is that the following day, paragraph 25, Themba Khoza came to collect the weapons.
	He says we were told that other policemen, not the policemen from Vereeniging, would come and search for weapons.  Khoza was very happy and praised the people at a rally that was held at the hostel the same day.  Your comment please?
I do not know anything about that.
You do know of course, that a decision was taken to burn the evidence from Boipatong or do you not?
I already told you that I do not have any knowledge thereof.
Do you know that a decision was taken to burn the evidence from Boipatong?

I don't know what else to tell you now, because you are asking me this question for the fourth or fifth time, and I have already told you I did not know that there was property that was looted from Boipatong.
	When I heard of it, I could not find the said property.
Do you know that that property was burnt?
No.  I think I should not respond to your question any more.
All right Mr Mkhize, I was giving you an opportunity to be clear, because at page 78 of your statement, you say the following - I learnt ... (intervention)

Page 78, it is a statement attached to his amnesty application, middle of the page, I learnt first the following day, I heard first the following day that many people had been killed.  Then you say some of the residents had brought to the hostel, goods which had been in the houses of Boipatong.  Then you say, it was decided to burn the evidence.  That is why I was asking you that question so many times, Mr Mkhize.
	Perhaps now you know about the decision to burn the evidence?
No, I do not remember any such decision.
Why is it in your statement then?
I do not know.  I do not know how it came about, I do not remember anything of this sort.

You know very well that it was Themba Khoza who ordered that the evidence was burnt, and you don't want to reveal that now, correct?  No comment?
	By the way the statement that we are referring to, was made by you on the 23rd of May 1998 and it was confirmed by you this morning, correct?

You were asked by your Advocate and you confirmed it.
	You say you have no knowledge about the rally in Ulundi, approximately one month after the attack on Boipatong?
I do not remember because there many rallies that were held.

Did anyone ever tell you that at this rally, the leader of the IFP, Chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi, had given a speech in which he thanked Mr Nosenga and others who were there for the good job that they had done in Boipatong?

That is not true.  The Chief would have never praised or thanked the people for doing something of this sort.
	No one amongst IFP members would have gone and informed the Chief about such an act.

I am reading from paragraph 26 on page 22 of Mr Nosenga's statement.  He also says in that same paragraph that they travelled in a kombi, driven by Darkie, that would be Darkie Qunchu.
	He says that Darkie's uncle owned the kombi.  You have told the Committee that Damara Qunchu owned a kombi, is that correct?
In the judgement of the criminal court, at page 295 to 297, the Judge found that you had been in possession of an AK47.  That finding is correct not so?

The Judge also found that a meeting had been held, well he said that although he was of the opinion that the attack on Boipatong must have been planned, well planned in advance, he couldn't say that there was enough evidence to prove that there was this meeting two weeks before the attack.
	We now know that there was such a meeting, correct?
The Judge also said at page 3744, 296 of the bundle, page 3744 of the record, that you confirmed - I am not sure, I am trying to translate from the Afrikaans.
Why don't you get somebody to do the translation, whilst you get on with the other questions?
Chairperson, I can understand Afrikaans, I am just trying not to be inaccurate.
Yes, then put the question to him.

You confirmed in court that as part of the military attire, bands were worn around the head and you also corroborated that Moses Mthembu, accused 73, Moses Mthembu, was a leader to the extent that you couldn't decide on your own that the residents should go out on attack.
	You required the approval of Moses Mthembu.  Do you remember saying that?
